bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence Reed, August 11, 1952

div1.p: Hench doubts that the dedication of Camp Lazear will take place in September 1952. He does not think that the Cuban government will be able to pay travel expenses for the attendees, and suggests ways that the U.S. Army or government might pay for the Reeds and Truby to attend. Hench thinks it would be appropriate for the United States to have an official representative at the dedication, and suggests that Love approach the Surgeon General about this.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Lawrence Reed, August 11, 1952
div1.opener:
August 11, 1952
General Walter L. Reed
2810 Thirty-Sixth Place, N.W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Reed:
div1.p:
Although Doctor Nogueira still hopes that the dedication of Camp Lazear
will be late in September and although I can see from the photographs he
has sent me that the work of grading and so on is well along, I still
doubt if it can be dedicated that soon. In any event, it would be a fine
thing if you and Mrs. Reed could attend the dedication. I am doubtful
that the Cuban Government will come across with much, if any, expense money
for guests despite the suggestions of Doctor Nogueira's letter (enclosed).
Do you think that the Surgeon General could remotivate you and possibly
also General Truby and send you and your wives to Cuba at Army expense just
long enough for the dedication, or would the Army or State Department have
other ways of appointing you as an official representative?

Assuming that the dedication may be the end of September, I think it is
imperative that the Surgeon General of the Army and the State Department
be informed of the matter and of the various conflicts behind this project.
Here is a wonderful chance to establish a new era in good feeling and get
rid of the old anti-Reed era in Cuba. Obviously Doctor Nogueira is anxious
to have appropriate American official sponsorship. I regret indeed that I
am leaving this Wednesday for a long-planned two and a half weeks' vacation
in Mexico. I enclose a letter I have sent to the Surgeon General. I wonder
if there is any possibility that you and General Love could go over this
data together and perhaps General Love could visit the Surgeon General first
and later, if necessary, the appropriate persons in the State Department
to see what they can do regarding representation. I can certainly see that
you would not want yourself to make this suggestion or visit the Surgeon
General in your own behalf. Certainly there should be a State Department
representative and I suppose it might be the American Ambassador in Cuba.
What is the possibility that Mrs. Blossom could go along with you and Mrs.
Reed?

If you have any suggestions and if you want me to do anything, my mail will
be forwarded to me, air mail, and I will handle matters from Mexico.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
Copies sent to Generals Love and Truby
